title: Miami, Oklahoma
text:
Miami ( ) is a city in and <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Ottawa%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Ottawa County, Oklahoma</a>, United States, founded in 1891. <a href="Lead">Lead</a> and <a href="zinc">zinc</a> mining established by 1918, caused it to boom.
This area was part of <a href="Indian%20Territory">Indian Territory</a>. Miami is the capital of the federally recognized <a href="Miami%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Miami Tribe of Oklahoma</a>, after which it is named; the <a href="Modoc%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Modoc Tribe of Oklahoma</a>, the <a href="Ottawa%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Ottawa Tribe of Oklahoma</a>, the <a href="Peoria%20%28tribe%29">Peoria Tribe of Indians</a>, and the <a href="Shawnee%20Tribe">Shawnee Tribe</a>. As of the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20census">2020 census</a>, the population was 12,969.
History.
Miami began in an unusual way, compared to other towns in <a href="Indian%20Territory">Indian Territory</a>. Per the "Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture" "... it was settled in a business-like way by men of vision who looked into the future and saw possibilities. It didn't just grow. It was carefully planned."
W. C. Lykins petitioned the <a href="U.S.%20Congress">U.S. Congress</a> to pass legislation on March 3, 1891, to establish the town. He met with Thomas F. Richardville, chief of the <a href="Miami%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Miami Tribe of Oklahoma</a>, who agreed to meet in turn with the <a href="Indian%20Commission">U.S. Indian Commission</a> and the <a href="Ottawa%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Ottawa Tribe</a>. 
That meeting resulted in Congress authorizing the <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20the%20Interior">secretary</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Interior">United States Department of the Interior</a> to approve the townsite purchase from the Ottawa. Lykins, Richardville and Manford Pooler, chief of the Ottawa, are identified in historical accounts as "fathers of Miami." Lykins' company, the Miami Town Company, bought of land from the Ottawa for ten dollars an acre. On June 25–26, 1891 they held an auction of lots. In 1895, Miami incorporated and had more than 800 residents.
The discovery of rich deposits of lead and zinc under <a href="Quapaw">Quapaw</a> land a few miles north caused Miami to boom. In 1907, at the time of statehood, its population was 1,893. As mining increased and more mills were built, the population increased to 6,802 by 1920.
Miami was on the route of the <a href="Jefferson%20Highway">Jefferson Highway</a> established in 1915, with that international road running more than from <a href="Winnipeg">Winnipeg</a>, Manitoba in Canada across the border and to <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a>, Louisiana. <a href="U.S.%20Route%2066%20in%20Oklahoma">US Route 66</a> in Oklahoma also passed through Miami. An historic <a href="U.S.%20Route%2066%20in%20Oklahoma%23Structures">section of the Route 66 roadbed</a> is marked in Miami.
It is the capital of the Miami Tribe of Oklahoma, after which it is named; the <a href="Modoc%20Tribe%20of%20Oklahoma">Modoc Tribe of Oklahoma</a>, Ottawa Tribe of Oklahoma, <a href="Peoria%20%28tribe%29">Peoria Tribe of Indians</a>, and <a href="Shawnee%20Tribe">Shawnee Tribe</a>.
Geography.
Miami is located near (36.883539, −94.876018). According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which is land and (0.82%) is water.
Flooding.
Miami is located on the <a href="Neosho%20River">Neosho River</a>, and was severely affected by the <a href="Great%20Flood%20of%201951">Great Flood of 1951</a>. The town has flooded more than two dozen times since the 1990s, most recently during the <a href="2019%20Arkansas%20River%20floods">2019 Arkansas River floods</a>. Town residents and neighboring Native American groups have objected to maintaining high water levels on the river at <a href="Pensacola%20Dam">Pensacola Dam</a> and its popular vacation area, <a href="Grand%20Lake%20o%27%20the%20Cherokees">Grand Lake</a>, on the grounds that when water backs up downstream, it can increase Miami's flooding problems.
Demographics.
As of the 2010 census, there were 13,570 people, 5,315 households, and 3,337 families residing in the city. a one percent decline from 13,704 at the 2000 census. The population density was 1,258.7 people per square mile (485.9/km). The racial makeup of the city was 68.9% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">white</a>, 1.3% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 17.1% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.5% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 2% <a href="Pacific%20Islander%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 2.1% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 8% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race made up 4.8% of the population.
There were 5,315 households, out of which 31.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 44.6% were married couples living together, 15% had a female householder with no husband present, and 36.2% were non-families. Single individuals living alone accounted for 31.9% of households and individuals 65 years of age or older living alone accounted for 14.7% of households. The average household size was 2.46 and the average family size was 3.07.
In the city, the population was spread out, with 24.7% under the age of 18, 57.1% from 18 to 64, and 18.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35.8 years. The population was 53.2% female and 46.8% male.
The median income for a household in the city was $34,561, and the median income for a family was $42,313. Males had a median income of $32,699 versus $25,320 for females. About 14.2% of families and 19.2% of the population were below the poverty line.
In 2020, about one in four residents lived in poverty.
Government.
Local government in Miami consists of an elected Mayor at-large and four councilmen representing four Wards.
As of 2015, the city is represented in the <a href="Oklahoma%20House%20of%20Representatives">Oklahoma House of Representatives</a> by Democrat <a href="Ben%20Loring">Ben Loring</a>, and in the <a href="Oklahoma%20Senate">Oklahoma Senate</a> by Republican <a href="Micheal%20Bergstrom">Micheal Bergstrom</a>. The city lies within <a href="Oklahoma%27s%202nd%20congressional%20district">Oklahoma's 2nd congressional district</a>, represented by <a href="Markwayne%20Mullin">Markwayne Mullin</a> since 2013.
Transportation.
Miami is on <a href="Interstate%2044%20in%20Oklahoma">Interstate 44</a> and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2069%20in%20Oklahoma">U.S. Route 69</a>, and is approximately from <a href="U.S.%20Route%2059%20in%20Oklahoma">U.S. Route 59</a>.
Pelivan Transit, owned and operated by Grand Gateway EDA & Northeast Oklahoma Tribal Transit Consortium, provides a trolley loop in Miami, as well as certain on-demand bus services.
Miami is served by Miami Regional Airport (KMIO; FAA Identifier MIO), with a paved runway. Commercial air transportation is available from Joplin Regional Airport, about northeast, or Tulsa International Airport, about southwest.
Coleman Theatre and historical buildings.
Miami and Ottawa County, together with nearby <a href="Delaware%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Delaware County, Oklahoma</a> to the south, attract numerous tourists to the state. These counties combined make up the third-largest tourism destination in the state, following only the <a href="Oklahoma%20City">Oklahoma City</a> and <a href="Tulsa">Tulsa</a> metropolitan areas.
Miami is home to the historic Coleman Theatre, located at 103 N. Main St. On April 18, 1929, the 1,600-seat Coleman Theatre enjoyed a grand opening as a luxurious movie theater of the time. Designed by the <a href="Boller%20Bros.">Boller Bros.</a>, and built by George L. Coleman Sr. at a cost of $600,000, the Louis XV interior includes <a href="gold%20leaf">gold leaf</a> trim, silk <a href="damask">damask</a> panels, <a href="stained%20glass">stained glass</a> panels, marble accents, a carved <a href="mahogany">mahogany</a> staircase, <a href="Wurlitzer">Wurlitzer</a> pipe organ, decorative plaster moldings, and bronze railings. While there have been many changes to seeing movies in grand theaters, the building has been preserved and also serves as a venue for live performances. In 1959 a local non-profit community group established the Miami Little Theatre. The community theater group presents five large-scale productions on the Coleman stage every year. In 1983, the Coleman Theatre was placed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places%20listings%20in%20Ottawa%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">National Register of Historical Places for Ottawa County</a>. 
Other Miami structures are also listed on the National Register of Historical Places, including the <a href="George%20L.%20Coleman%20Sr.%20House">George L. Coleman Sr. House</a>, the <a href="Miami%20Marathon%20Oil%20Company%20Service%20Station">Miami Marathon Oil Company Service Station</a>, and the <a href="Miami%20Downtown%20Historic%20District">Miami Downtown Historic District</a>.
Education.
Public schools serving most of Miami are managed by the <a href="Miami%20Public%20Schools">Miami Public Schools</a> school district. The high school is Miami High School, whose mascot is the Wardog. The Wardog is a mascot unique to Miami and has not been adopted as a mascot by any other school in the United States.
A portion of northern Miami is ithin the <a href="Commerce%20Public%20Schools">Commerce Public Schools</a> school district.
<a href="Northeastern%20Oklahoma%20A%26amp%3BM%20College">Northeastern Oklahoma A&M College</a> was accredited initially in 1925 by the <a href="North%20Central%20Association%20of%20Colleges%20and%20Schools">North Central Association of Colleges and Schools</a>. In addition to its certificate programs, it has working relationships with other higher education institutions in the state to promote transfers of students seeking four-year college degrees. In 2015 the two-year community college had about 2,000 students.
